content: SEC. 1259 introduces constructive sales treatment for appreciated financial positions in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If there is a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position, the taxpayer must recognize gain as if the position were sold for its fair market value on the date of the sale. Any gain must be included in the taxable year of the sale. Adjustments will be made for any subsequent gain or loss realized with respect to the position. If there is a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position, adjustments will be made for any subsequent gain or loss realized with respect to the position. The holding period of the position will be determined as if it were originally acquired on the date of the constructive sale. A taxpayer is considered to have made a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position if there would be gain upon selling the position. The term "position" includes interests like futures contracts, short sales, and options. Adjustments will be made for any subsequent gain or loss realized after a constructive sale, with the holding period determined as if the position was acquired on the date of the sale. The term 'offsetting notional principal contract' refers to an agreement to pay the investment yield on a property in exchange for reimbursement for any decline in its value. The term 'offsetting notional principal contract' involves paying the investment yield on a property in exchange for reimbursement for any decline in its value, including appreciation, for a specified period. Section 1259 of the Internal Revenue Code applies to constructive sales of appreciated financial positions, with a special rule for decedents dying after the enactment of the Act. The rule states that the constructive sale is treated as occurring 30 days after the date of enactment. The Act specifies that if there was a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position before the enactment date, and the transaction is open before the decedent's death with no recognized gain, then the position is treated as open for tax purposes. The Act specifies that if there was a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position before the enactment date, and the transaction is open before the decedent's death with no recognized gain, then the position is treated as open for tax purposes. In such cases, the position is treated as property constituting rights to receive an item of income in respect of a decedent under the Internal Revenue Code. LIMITATION ON EXCEPTION FOR INVESTMENT COMPANIES UNDER SECTION 351. Amends section 351(e) of the Internal Revenue Code to include all stock and securities held by a company in determining if it is an investment company. Effective for transfers after the enactment date in taxable years ending after that date.
